Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017 IEEE Cyber Security Development (SecDev)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This grant supports student attendance to the IEEE Cyber Security Development (SecDev) conference. Research on software security usually focuses on detecting vulnerabilities in software and attacks on resources. However, there is not much attention to how programmers can develop secure software by construction. This new conference series on Secure Development (SecDev) focuses on this problem area. The support for the conference is important for educating/training the workforce in this area, and to help provide a pathway to research careers. The technical advances presented and nurtured by the conference are important to development of secure software, which is important to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2017 SecDev Conference brought together a community of practitioners, researchers, policy makers, and students to share ideas on "building-in" cyber security. This funding provided by the NSF for this project served to financially support undergraduate and graduate student participation in the conference. The award solicitation received 10 applications from 8 universities. The 10 applicants included 9 Graduate and 1 Undergraduate student. The project provided:

  • 8 Student awards, which included 2 women applicants and 1 applicant from a HBCU
  • Outreach to nearly 50 Universities/Colleges, including HBCUs, to provide awareness and encouragement to participate in a community engaged in cyber security
  • Opportunity for students to present and share their research with a community of accomplished researchers
  • Opportunity to engage in dialog on new research ideas and directions, as well as forming new collaborations
  • Student access to:
    • 3 Keynote speakers from Google, Facebook, and Dell/EMC
    • Panel Discussion with cyber security professionals from: DHS, The Engine, Veracode, Synopsys, and BitSight
    • 2 Tutorial Sessions, with 3 tracks each
    • Poster Session with 7 papers
    • 4 Technical paper sessions
    • 9 Lightning talks
    • Birds of-a Feathers session for Women in Cyber Security

The NSF award funds provide for broader societal benefit by supporting student participation, as well as intellectual merit through the presentation and flourish of new ideas for "building-in" cyber security.


Last Modified: 03/30/2018
Modified by: Vineet Mehta
